text:
ANITA WOOD: It is my
pleasure to introduce

to you our guest speaker
today, Julie Stanford.

Julie is a founder of Sliced
Bread Design, a user research

and experience
design agency that

is at the forefront of
interactive design in Silicon

Valley, and the CEO
of eDNA Explorer.

Julie has spent the
last two decades

helping companies design
compelling interactive products
and services.

She is a lecturer at Stanford
University in the Computer

Science Department,
where she teaches Design
for AI and Service Design.

Julie also teaches in our
Stanford Online Digital
Transformation Program.

She teaches XDGT115,
Human-Centered Design
for Digital Transformation.
Welcome, Julie.

JULIE STANFORD: Great, good
to see all of you today.

As Anita mentioned,
we're going to be talking

about putting people back into
digital transformation, which

in just even the
language implies
it's all about technology.

But it actually, in my
view, is not about that.

And so Anita shared with you
a little bit of my background,

so I won't go into all
the things about me.

But sometimes people ask me,
is there anything out there

that I could see that
you actually designed?

And probably my favorite
thing that I worked on is--

if you have an electric car and
you ever go charge your car,

we worked on the
first version of that,

thinking about how to really
implement not just the user

experience for people who
are pulling up to charge

but also how the entire service
works in terms of the-- how

these stations are serviced and
all the kind of digital work

that had to go on behind the
scenes to really manage them.

And so that's probably the best
place to see some of the stuff
I've worked on.

Or you can check out my latest
project at eDNA Explorer.
But let's not talk about that.

Hopefully, you
guys at this point

think I might know
what I'm talking about.

Let's actually dig in and talk
about digital transformation.

So when you hear the words
"digital transformation,"
it could mean a lot of things.

And so I just did some
work and kind of looked up

some definitions online that
I'm going to read to you.
So what is it?

It's the redesign and
automation of a business process

that is currently
manual, time-consuming,
and prone to errors.

It's some kind of transformation
to improve efficiency, reduce

errors and costs, and overall,
the customer experience,

for a key business process such
as HR, finance, accounting.

I'm going to kind of trail off
because I think I fell asleep
by the end of that sentence.

And it makes this area feel
really dry because what's
missing from these definitions?

The people who are really at the
core of using this technology.

Any technology
that you introduce

that is going to be used,
no matter what it is,

somewhere down the
line, there's going

to be a person who's choosing
to engage with it, who

has a whole point of view
and a set of stories and all

these things that they're
bringing to their work.

And that richness is really
missing from these definitions

and is one of the reasons,
I would say the top reason,

that if you look across
a lot of work that

has been done in this space, a
lot of it ends up in this land

that I'm going to call the
Land of Unfortunate Digital
Transformations, right?

Things that people were
super excited about,

that took months or
sometimes even years,

and were millions of
dollars to implement.

And then they're
just not really used

or they're not really having the
impact that people were really
hoping they would have.

And I'll give you a really
great example of that

that I just heard
recently on a podcast,

that I thought was
one of the best

examples of this Land
of Unfortunate Digital
Transformations.
And that's bodycams in policing.

I don't know if you recall
but a number of years

ago, there was this big
movement about, hey,

we're really going to
digitally transform policing.

And the way we're going
to do that, we're going
to avoid the he said, she said.

And we're going to have
police wear these bodycams.

And then we're
really going to know,

through the power of digital
video, what actually happened

in encounters where there
is some confusion about what

went on and there's a
real need for oversight.

So let's fast forward
to 2024, and there's

been some research
done, like what's

been the impact
of this incredibly

big digital transformation
in the policing space?

And actually,
unfortunately, the impact
hasn't really been that great.

As a matter of fact,
in a lot of places,

the impact has been
almost unmeasurable.
It's so small.
So why is that?

Why is this thing that had so
much potential in this scrap
heap here?

Well, if you kind of take a
look and dig a little deeper,

it turns out that even
though these bodycams have

been implemented and
police are wearing them,

control over who the
video is shared with

is in the hands of
police departments, which
on the face of it, makes sense.

But then the oversight boards
who would like to see the video
have to ask for it.

And the police department
and a lot of-- most places
has the ability to say no.

And there's a lot of reasons why
people wouldn't want to share
video that might be damaging.

And it turns out, if
you look even closer

and you go back in time
to before the bodycams,

there was actually a lot of
data that police departments

had-- that wasn't
digital necessarily,

that was available
to support or deny

situations that needed to be
explored further-- that also
wasn't shared.

And so if you really kind
of look more closely,

you start seeing a pattern
that this really big case is

symbolic of that also
happens in a lot of really

small digital transformation
projects, where just injecting

the technology isn't actually
going to solve the problem.

You really need to take
a people-first look

at what's going on to
understand what's happening.

So when I say a
human-centered approach

to digital transformation,
injecting the people back in,

what I'm talking about
is really trying to--

at the beginning of
any of these projects

and then continuing
throughout, trying

to solve for the real
problem that's at hand.

So in this policing
case, was the problem

that there wasn't
enough information about
what happened in the situation?

Or was the problem
more structural?

And was there something
around the process

for how information is shared
or how rules are structured

around oversight or what
the different incentives are

for sharing or not
sharing information?

Might those have been the root
causes or the real situations
that needed to be addressed?
I don't know.

This isn't an area I've
explored-- have not explored.

But at the end of
the day, just like in

this policing situation, which
is really grand, in the areas

I have explored, where
people come in and ask me,

can you help us either design
this digital transformation

or figure out why the thing we
launched isn't really working,
it's the people always.

It's always the people that are
the reason the transformation

does or doesn't have
impact in terms of, again,

how they're involved in
the delivery of a service

or what the processes are
or what their incentives are
or what's happening.

And so I want to talk
today about some techniques

for really creating
an insurance policy

against dead digital
transformation projects

so that yours doesn't
end up in the scrap heap,

not having the impact
that you're really
hoping it will have.

And one really important
way to think about that

is this tool or
mindset of reframing,

which is taking an old
problem that everyone's

really familiar with,
be it some HR problem

or some customer
problem or some--

I recently worked
on a project that

was just around how
ticketing systems work
in customer support.

And can we reframe
this old problem

from a new point of
view that maybe we
hadn't considered before?

Like in this picture, maybe if
instead of looking at things

that captures the
old way of thinking,

we can capture some
new perspectives
that we hadn't even considered.

And so frames are
these new perspectives

you take to orient you to a new
space of potential solutions.

Tina Seelig, who is one
of my favorite people

in the design thinking
human-centered design space,

said, quote, "All questions are
the frame into which answers
fall.

By changing the frame,
you dramatically

change the range of
possible solutions."

And we can think of some
really great examples

of that are just in the everyday
world, for example, Target.

The original frame
in the, I'd say,

'80s is that discount
stores are for people
who want cheap stuff.

And then Target came
along and said, ha,

we have a new frame
on this problem.

What if people who
shop at discount stores

are actually people who deeply
value designer products?

It's not that they're
looking for cheap stuff,

it's that they really
actually want designer stuff.

It's just they can't
afford it quite yet.

And is there an
opportunity to make

a different kind of discount
store with this new frame?

Or Airbnb, maybe the
old frame around travel

is that travel is all about
staying apart from the locals.
You come somewhere.
You stay in a hotel.
You go to tourist sites.

And then that's what
travel looks like.

And their new frame,
which has really

transformed their industry, is
that people who travel actually

want to collect with locals
and share local resources.
That's what travel is all about.

And staying in a hotel or
visiting just the tourist sites

isn't really what people are
valuing most from travel.

And so what does that
mean for our business?

Or-- and this is totally not
in any way a digital example--

Coca-Cola had this
insight in the '90s where

they looked at soda boxes and
they said, what can we do here
that's innovative?

And they talked to
a bunch of people.

And they realized
actually what's

happening is people often
have soda in their fridge,
they just can't find it.

And so they realize
maybe soda boxes are not
for transporting soda.

They're actually a tool to
help people find and store soda

in the fridge, which
led to the design

of this alternative version of
a soda box that's really long.
It fits in your fridge nicely.
The front opens up.

And then people can see
where their soda is.

Small, small
insight, big impact.

So this reframing idea, I'm
sure you've heard of it before.
It's not a new concept.

But it's really not
used to its advantage.

So in 1992, there was a
study by Professor Paul Nutt
at Ohio State.
I love his name.

And it looked at the
influence of various tactics
on success in decision-making.

And the way the
study worked is he

looked at 168 cases, all kinds
of companies across the US

and Canada doing all
kinds of different things.

The decisions really varied
in terms of the setting,

private, public, nonprofit, what
level the decision-maker was,

if it was a C level or
a VP level executive

or someone who was a lower
level manager or an employee

without any management, where
they got information from,

how important the
problem was-- wide range.
You got the picture.

And he was trying to
understand how did the--

how the formulation of the
problem, the way the problem

was thought about
from the beginning,

how did that
influence the success

and the outcomes of the
solution for that problem?

And he identified four tactics
for formulating a problem.

One was the idea
tactic, like, oh.

This is the problem where
we're like, we have an idea.
We have a technology.

And we're really
excited about it.

And we're just looking for
what it's going to fix.

So you're coming at this
space with a specific idea
of some new cool thing.

Let's take bodycams, and you're
like, oh, I love bodycams.
They're so impactful.

Let's just find a
place to stick them.

Or a problem tactic, where the
problem is presented to you

and it's framed in a very
specific way like, oh,

the issue with policing is
that we aren't sure what's
going on in a given situation.

We need to find a way
to solve for that.

Or hey, there's this HR
problem at our company
where salaries aren't equal.

And so we need a way
to solve for that.

And so there's just a specific
kind of problem statement.

A target tactic
is the third one.

That's when you describe
a problem by saying,

we really have a
specific target we

need to meet to increase
our sales by 25%,

or we need to reduce the
number of negative calls

to customer support by 10%
or something like that.

And then the last one
is the reframing tactic,

where you say, oh, there's a
problem space like, hey, here's
this problem we're observing.

But what we're
going to do is we're

going to first take a
step back and understand

what the problem actually
is, and then reframe it.

And what he found is that
tactic, reframing, was

by far and away the most
effective tactic in terms

of outcomes, that the problems
where people whenever,

whatever-- however the problem
was initially presented,

whether it was presented
as an idea or a problem

or a target or something
else, if that group

or person managing
it said, let's

take a step back first
and investigate and really

understand what
the root causes are

so we can reframe this space,
those solutions and outcomes

had the highest likelihood
of being really successful.

And by successful, I mean
they were implemented quickly.
They were adopted.

And they led to
an actual increase

in whatever metric was being
applied to understand success
in that situation.

Unfortunately, this technique
was the least likely
to be used.
Why is that?

Well, it seems like
at the beginning,

you're spending
more time on things

than on understanding
the problems
and on actually solving it.
And so it feels slow.

But in fact, it's
slow at the beginning
so that it's fast later on.

And that kind of
mismatch often makes

people feel like
they're either not

empowered to take a reframing
approach or there's just
not enough time to take it.

And it's fascinating
because that's actually

the approach that's going
to lead to the biggest
likelihood of success.
So how do you do it?

How do you take this
reframing approach?

We're going to go back to
just the title of this talk.

You connect with
the humans involved.

Technology always exists,
it's part of a human system.

And you have to understand
all the different complexities

of the system so that when
you introduce something

new, like a digital
transformation,

it fits into the way that
people actually do their work

and changes all the other
pieces of the system that

need to be changed to
support the new idea.

And in fact, the new idea
will probably be different

because it will emerge from an
understanding of who are all
the different parties involved.

Is it just the police
or is it the oversight

board, and these people,
and those people?

And who are all the
different parties

that are kind of coming
together in this situation?
What is really happening?

What do we understand
about this problem?
When are these things happening?

When are problems being
introduced-- at the beginning,
the middle, or the end?
Or where along the way?
Where is this work taking place?
And why?

most importantly, why are
we seeing the problems
that we're seeing?

Can we take a fresh view to
really systemically understand

everything about all
the humans involved?

And there's a lot of different
diagrams of a process

that you take to follow this
human-centered approach.

This is my favorite
one because I

feel it really
reflects the way that I

think about this space, which
is following a cyclical loop.

So you start by saying, I really
want to reframe and understand
this problem.
And so I'm going to observe.

I'm going to interview
people who are involved.

And I'm going to
hear what they say.
I'm going to see what they do.

And I'm also going
to listen, this

is going to sound
really new-agey,

what's in their
heart, meaning, I'm

going to try to understand
what's really motivating them

to make the decisions
that they're

making, not just logistically
but as an individual person.

And then I'm going to take the
results of those interviews
and observations.

And I'm going to develop some
new frames, the insights that I

have about the
problem that maybe I
didn't understand before.

That this policing issue,
maybe it's not about he said,
she said.

It's just about who
owns information
or how information is shared.

And if you address that
problem, you don't even
need the digital cameras.

Or imagine how
impactful they would

be if that piece of
the puzzle was included
as part of the transformation.

You take the insights that
you have about really the root
causes of the problem.

You develop some
concepts that reflect
what the human needs are here.

You prototype them
really quickly,

pushing yourself to prototype
as fast as possible so that you

can bring your prototypes out
to people, get their feedback,

and continue around this
loop-- usually, I would say,
probably two to four times--

until you're really at a
place that you feel like,
I get this problem.

And I'm really ready
to press forward.

So this type of work,
where you're really

understanding humans and then
moving forward with input

from them at each
step, happens all

along the path of a
digital transformation

from the foundation, through
selecting the solution,
to implementing it.

So initially, when you're
thinking about, OK,

what am I even
going to solve for?
What frame do I have?

You do some foundational work,
which we call needfinding here
at Stanford.
And the name says it all.
I am looking for needs.
And I am a detective.

And I am finding
what is happening.

I am doing a thorough
investigation,

interviewing people, as
I said, to understand

that 360 of their needs,
their context, who else

are they working
with-- the whole system

so that I can really
create a strong foundation.

And if I don't have
this foundation,

then by the time I
get to the next step,

I'm not going to be solving
for the right thing.

And so my space of
idea possibility, it's
going to be too narrow.

Then when I start-- when
I have that foundation,

I can start coming up
with all kinds of ideas
so that I can select a solution.

And here, I follow a technique
for observation and user

research that I call
rapid experimentation,

where you validate
ideas with people

by running really
basic experiments that

are time-boxed, where you
say, OK, I only have two days.

And the next two days, I'm
not just going to ask people,

hey, what do you
think about this idea?

I'm going to find a way to
experientially prototype it

so that people actually know
how this idea might work.

I'll give you a really great
example that's pretty quick.

A few years ago, we were
working on just redesigning

the directory for a company,
how their corporate directory

worked, because they
realized that based

on this foundational work,
that one of the key things that

was actually undermining
the ability of employees

to communicate is that their
corporate directory was really

outdated, really small
problem with a potential
for a lot of impact.

And one of the biggest insights
we had in the foundation

is that people's titles in
the directory were wrong,
again, really small insight.

But people would be confused
before they talk to someone

or even tried to reach out
to someone at their company

because they couldn't
figure out like, what

was this person actually
doing here at our company?

They had a lot of reorgs, and
the corporate directory just
couldn't catch up.

And so we had this idea,
really small idea, of what

if there was some
way to recruit people

to very easily verify
what their title is

in the directory with as
little effort as possible?
And so we ran an experiment.

And we picked a hundred
people at the company.

And we texted
them, the directory

says that your current title
is blah, blah, blah, blah.

If that's not right, text back
what your title actually is.

And we were looking to
measure what percent of people
actually texted back.
It was crazy.

65% of people
actually texted back,

this is not my
title, because who

wants to have wrong information
in a corporate directory,
right?

And it was so powerful
that this project

got greenlighted to
really build out a system

that automatically
regularly contacted people

to try to say, hey, here's the
information we have for you,

whether it's your title or other
information in the directory,

so that it could always
be accurate and up to date

and really easy to fix
without having someone

log in and so on
and so forth and get
into a morass of updates.

So that's an example of a
really successful experiment.

Often, the result is actually
you learn that intervention
isn't going to work.

And not only that,
you learn why.

And the faster you can
get to that learning

of what is working
or not working

and most importantly what
you can do to fix it,

the better it's
going to be as you

move into that final step of a
digital transformation project,
which is an implementation.

And there, we're continuing
to connect with people.

We're continuing to ask
people to look at the work

as it's-- the implementation
is in progress.

Sometimes we have
a panel of people

who are regular users at
our company or customers,

depending on what the
transformation is,

who are going to keep giving
us feedback to make sure

that we're really
staying on track,

understanding the frame
that people are bringing

to the space, and keeping
humans in the loop

so that we don't end up
in that unfortunate heap.

So again, in this space,
there's a lot to learn.

This is just the beginning of
a discussion about these three

skills of needfinding
interviews,

which has a lot of really
great techniques around stories

and how you pull specific
stories out of people

because it's the stories that
are going to help us understand

the problem best, how to
run rapid experiments,

what kind of
off-the-shelf tools you

can use to do that so
that you can quickly
have this bias towards action.

In one of my classes that I'm
actually teaching this quarter,

it is Rapid
Experimentation Week.

And I am pushing my
students, get out there.

I need you to run at least three
experiments by next Wednesday.
And today is Wednesday.

And people are
reluctant at first.

But once they do
it, they realize

it's so powerful that then
they bring that thinking out
to the workplace.

And it's so hard when you're
at a company to think, gosh,
I don't know.
Do I have approval?
Should I do it?

And I always advise, yeah, try
something out that's small.

What can you experiment
with that you can actually

see and get feedback
on something real,

not just ask people
what do they think?

And then the testing, how do
you create an ongoing plan

for really including people
in testing as a transformation
or in roles?

There's a lot to
think about there.

And so if you're interested
in hearing more from me

and want to have some
closer discussions of any

of these topics, you can
learn more in the larger class

that I teach on a human-centered
approach to transformation,

where we're going to really
dig into need-finding

and look at all the techniques
around interviewing either

for you to do it
or even just how
to look for a good interviewer.

As someone who's
run a design agency,

it's often really hard for me to
hire because I'm really looking
for some specific skills.

And hopefully I
can share with you

some ways that if you're
in a position where you're

either doing it
yourself or hiring,
you can know what to look for.

And then once you
have the data, let's

talk about how to synthesize
it so you can squeeze out

as much insight as you
can, so that then you

can frame the problem
in a novel way,

not just confirm what
you already know.

That's why we do research,
to learn new things.
So let's talk about that.

And then we're
going to talk a lot

about rapid experimentation--
how to do it,

how to build those
prototypes, how

to get some data by the end of
the day or the end of the week

so that you can make
decisions really focused

on what humans think
about what's going on
and what they do.

How you analyze and share that
data to bring people along

in your team so that you
can, again, have impact

beyond just you
and the few people

you work with but on
a larger organization
to get things funded.

And then how to really
integrate this research

into your work in an ongoing
way so that you can continue

to pull in people
throughout all the steps

of a digital
transformation project.

And I think with that,
I'm just about at time

and would love to
hear your questions,

happy to chat about
any of these topics.

As you can tell, this is an
area I'm really passionate about

and would love to empower
people to do some of this work.
ANITA WOOD: Thank you, Julie.

We have enough time
for one question.

And I'm seeing some
questions come in.

And there's a focus on the topic
about data analysis, right?
Data, data, data, generative AI.

And I know your course
teaches some best practices

for sharing analysis results
when you're analyzing data
and sharing results.

Can you describe,
very quickly, one best

practice you could
give everybody one
to help in this area?
What would you recommend?

JULIE STANFORD: For
analyzing results?

ANITA WOOD: Yeah,
and sharing out.

JULIE STANFORD:
Yeah, so [CHUCKLES] I

think the best way and one
reason to date I've not

found GenAI to be great
for analyzing my results,

even though I keep
trying it, is you

are looking in your analysis
for specific examples of things

that are broken,
not generalizations
that go across everything.
Why is that?

People are really great at
solving specific problems.

And we're awful at solving
general problems, like really,
really stunningly bad.

And you can think
about just problems

in your day-to-day life with
your family or whoever else.

As soon as you have a
specific story, suddenly
you have all kinds of ideas.

But if someone just tells you,
I don't know, this is broken.
I don't know how to solve that.

So in your analysis,
I would really

urge people to
look at the stories

that you hear from people,
not just statistics

but actually, gosh, this is a
real person with a real example
of why this is broken.

And can I use that both to
help me think about a solution

and in sharing out with
people, to bring people along
for the ride?

Can I share a specific
example of a specific story

so that everyone understands
the depth of the problem

from the perspective
of an individual?

That's what's going to
make the most impact.
ANITA WOOD: Excellent.

Thank you for sharing that,
giving people, our listeners

out there some insight of what
they can learn in your course.

And this has been
fabulous, Julie.
Thank you so very much.

We are about at time, so this
is a perfect ending point.

And sorry we cannot get to
all those other questions.

But as you can see
on your screen,

if you would like to learn
more about the digital

transformation
program and courses,

there are links on the interface
that you can select and go

to the program page and then see
the course that Julie teaches.

I want to thank Julie
again for joining us

today and participating
in this excellent webinar.
And with that.

I want to thank everyone
today for joining us.
And it has been a pleasure.

And we wish you all a
great rest of your day.
Thanks for joining us.
